editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: VOX SOLIS: OR, An ASTROLOGICAL DISCOURSE OF The great ECLIPSE of the SUN, which happened on June 22. 1666. in 10 deg. of the Watry ≈øigne Cancer.
SHEWING What EFFECTS may mo≈øt probably attend it, AND Unto what Per≈øons, Kingdoms and Countries, they are chiefly Directed.

By JOHN GADBURY,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
With Allowance.
Intended to have been publi≈øht in his Ephemeris for this pre≈øent year 1667. but prevented by rea≈øon of the late terrible Conflagration of London.

q.p: Sol & Luna, post Deum, omnium viventium vita ≈øunt.

div.p: London, Printed by James Cotterel, for Eliz. Calvert, at the ≈øigne of the Black Spread-Eagle in Duck-lane. MDCLXVII.

div.head: To the TRUELY LEARNED, And mo≈øt WORTHILY ACCOMPLISHED, Elias A≈øhmole, Of the Middle-Temple, E≈øq;
Wind≈øor-Herald, Comptroller of the Exci≈øe, and Keeper of the Medals and Antiquities belonging to his ≈øacred Maje≈øtie King CHARLES the Second, &c.
div.p:
THe A≈øtrologers of this Age and I≈øland, ≈øwarm to You, as their Patron, (for ≈øhelter and protection of Them≈øelves and Books) as Bees to their Hive. It is an Argument of
true Sapience (I confe≈øs) to lodge the choice≈øt Jewels, in the Noblest Cabinets: And the Worthiest Sciences, fare always be≈øt, with the mo≈øt Honourable Mecoenas. Such Policie I approve of, and (although, at ≈øome times, (by rea≈øon of Tortuous interpo≈øures) I could not, yet) ≈øhall now, follow. For, when after-Ages ≈øhall under≈øtand, that I have made, not the meanest Additions to this Celestial Study; It may rea≈øonably put them into Admiration, if not A≈øtoni≈øhment, not to finde me, ≈øet within ≈øome convenient di≈øtance of your honourable Acquaintance and Favour.

'Tis true, in the twilight of Great Britains hope, and Re≈øtauration by his Sacred Majesty, [when it was a Crime, either to be known Loyal, or to own any one of that (then-de≈øpi≈øed) inclination and Judgement] I, with another, did pre≈øent unto You, An Emendation of the Learned Hartgil's A≈øtronomical Tables; which Book, You were plea≈øed generou≈øly, not onely to accept, and approve of, but nobly to encourage us, to a farther Enquiry into the Mysteries of that Science we had then e≈øpou≈øed.

But ≈øingly, have I never yet payd my Acknowledgements, or the honour I owe, unto your exqui≈øite Skill in all Mathematical, Hermetical, and Phy≈øical Learning; your eminent acquaintance with the Con≈øtitutions, Cu≈øtoms, and Manners of our own, and forraign Nations; your Admirable Knowledge in the Law, Heraldry, &c. as al≈øo, in all Politiques and Ethicks: Be plea≈øed (learned Sir) to accept it here.

I di≈ødain to make you Patron of my Gall and Rudene≈øs, as ≈øome (without a Blu≈øh) have lately done: or yet, to play the Para≈øite with You, and propound a Gain to my ≈øelf, by this Undertaking. No: my Dedication of the≈øe few Sheets of Paper, proceeds (ex intimis Medullis) not from a Spurious, but Legitimate honour and affection, and a de≈øire to let the Learned, in times to come, know, That no Artist in this Age, had a more Cordial e≈øteem for You, and your incomparable Vertues; or, could more readily acknowledge, your continued, and often-reiterated Favours, to the ingenious Students in all Learning, then He, who
a≈ø≈øumes the boldne≈øs, (and accounts it his greate≈øt Glory) to entitle him≈øelf

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt humble, and mo≈øt obliged Servant, JOHN GADBURY.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p: THe Heavens of late years, have not been laden with more various Cau≈øes, and Monitors of en≈øuing Mi≈øchiefs, then the Earth hath been burdened with ≈øutable Effects. No ≈øooner have we been quit of one Evil, but our Ears have been terrified with the noi≈øe of another's approach; like that of Job's me≈ø≈øengers. Poor Europe hath laboured under many of I≈øraels heavie Judgements; perhaps, de≈øerved them as much as ≈øhe; for her Hypocri≈øie, Pride, Rebellion, &c. And the two thundering Ver≈øes in Deuteronomie, Chap. 28. v. 21, 22. have been notably fulfilled unto (almost) all the ≈øeveral Kingdoms and Countries therein: Faciet Jehova ut adhaere≈øcat tibi Pe≈øtis, donec con≈øump≈øerit te ex ea terra quo tu venturus es ad po≈ø≈øidendam eam jure haereditario. Percutiet te Jehova tabe, calidaque, & ae≈øtuante ac adurente Febre, & ≈øiccitate & uridine, & morbo regio; quae per≈øequuntur te donec pereas.

The late Sufferings of this We≈øtern part of the world, do eminently Engli≈øh the most of the Latine: We have been ≈ømitten with the Pe≈øtilence to purpo≈øe; as al≈øo, with the Con≈øumption, and Fever; with the Sword, and extreme Burning: yea, a different, and (perhaps) more dreadful Burning, then that mentioned in the Text. God of his mercy grant, we be not pur≈øued with Bla≈øting and Mildew
too, to make up the complement of our puni≈øhments, which doubtle≈øs are the ju≈øt rewards of our Sins. A Learned Dr. Gell, in a Sermon intituled, Noahs floud returning, p. 15. Preacher ob≈øerving the vitious inclinations of the men of this Age (≈øome years ≈øince) parallels us with Sodom, thus: They of Sodom prefigured the men of this unclean generation; and mu≈øt not we expect a like Judgement unto that of Sodom? And (when we call to minde the late ≈øtrange providences) we may for ever hereafter believe it, for a divine and infallible Truth, That like Sins, have like Puni≈øhments.

But there is hopes of a tree, (though cut down) that it may ≈øprout again! and I have a more-then-ordinary rea≈øon to believe, (and I hope I do not deceive my ≈øelf therein) that Englands afflictions are neer their period: and can therefore with the more confidence, adde this word of Comfort unto it, That the Famine, threatned by the late Solar Delinquium, is not likely to prove the tythe ≈øo ≈øharp and cruel unto this Kingdom, as unto many other Kingdoms and Countries in this part of the world. [Jupiter is in Aries.] Yet I cannot ≈øay, that we ≈øhall be totally free, from the talons of that black and dreadful enemy. Deus avertat. So prayeth, the earne≈øt Implorer of Englands peace and pro≈øperity,

div.head: A DISCOURSE Of the SUNS ECLIPSE Which happened on June 22. la≈øt pa≈øt, in the morning.
div.p: IN my Ephemeris for. this pre≈øent year 1666, I declared to the World my re≈øolution to publi≈øh a Treati≈øe of this great Solar Eclip≈øe: which promi≈øe I had (according to engagement) di≈øcharged in my DIARY for the en≈øuing year 1667. having much enlarged the ≈øame, and obtained Licen≈øe, thereof, for that very end and purpo≈øe.

But the late dreadful Conflagration happening to London, wrought ≈øo great a de≈øtruction among the Stationers and Printers in that Citie, (they ≈øuffering the mo≈øt by the Tyrannical Flames, of any one Society what≈øoever) that I was con≈øtrained to reduce my Annual Book to its old number of Sheets, and re≈øerve my Di≈øcour≈øe of the Eclip≈øe to be printed apart by ≈øelf. And conceiving it to be of convenient Caution and Con≈øequence, not onely
to England, but other parts of Europe, &c. I thought it proper, rather then ≈øtifle it, (after ≈øo much pains) to print it. For although the Eclip≈øe it ≈øelf be over, its effects are to come; and may continue among us (if A≈øtrologie fail me not, as ≈øeldome it doth) the≈øe two years yet: (of which more anon.) I therefore pre≈øume this ≈øhort Tractate will not appear like an unfortunate Gue≈øt, (post Festum) after the Table is clear'd; but very opportunely, for the Information and Advantage of ≈øuch as are thereby concerned.

I need not (for an Exordium) acquaint you, that Eclip≈øes have been always attended with A≈øtoni≈øhing Effects; or that at the ≈øight of them, whole Armies have been ≈ømitten with amazement, fear, and horrour: or of the ≈øcorching Summers, unkinde Winters, de≈øtructions of Countries, ruines of Cities and Towns, the death of Kings and Great per≈øons, alterations of Governments, change of Laws, &c. that commonly accompany them. All the≈øe things I ≈øhall (at pre≈øent) pretermit, and come to the Di≈øcour≈øe intended; which I will con≈øider,

In the A≈øtronomical part, I ≈øhall fir≈øt take notice of ≈øome Notable Ob≈øervations that have been made of this Eclip≈øe, by ≈øeveral eminent per≈øons in different places; which I ≈øhall exhibit in the following Tabular form.

table.head: This Eclip≈øe was ob≈øerved in the following places.

div.p: The Reader need not much to wonder at the Differences of the≈øe Ob≈øervations, if he do but con≈øider they were taken in ≈øeveral places, where the Pole hath a different Elevation; and that the Parallax might materially differ. Yet it ≈øeems a little ≈øtrange, that there ≈øhould be le≈øs difference between tho≈øe Ob≈øervations made at London and Paris, then betwixt them made at London, and tho≈øe at Southampton and Oxford. But the Errour thereof may be occa≈øion'd from the imperfection of the In≈øtruments the Arti≈øts made u≈øe of; or el≈øe, for want of Exactne≈øs in the ob≈øervers them≈øelves: it being ea≈øier (in any thing) to be overtaken by Errours and Mi≈øtakes, then to keep pace with Truth and Certainty; chiefly, in A≈øtronomical Ob≈øervations.

With the mo≈øt concurrent of the≈øe Ob≈øervations, do the Rudolphine and Philolaick Tables agree; ≈øo al≈øo do tho≈øe of my loving friend Mr. V. Wing, and our Country-man Mr. Jeremy Shackerly. The Ricciolan and Lansbergian, &c. are found to differ much, both in the beginning, continuation,
termination, and ob≈øcuration of this eminent and famous Eclip≈øe.
But next unto the ≈øafe≈øt Ob≈øervations, do I prefer Mr. Wing's Tables, where you will finde this Solar deliquium

This premi≈øed, I ≈øhall in the next place con≈øider (with Ptolomy) how many hours there are (on the day of the Defect) between Sun-ri≈øing and the middle-time of the Eclip≈øe; unto which A≈øtrologers always erect their Figure of heaven. For take notice (≈øaith the ≈øame Author) how many hours the Sun is Eclip≈øed, for ≈øo many years ≈øhall be the duration of his Effect.

list.item: Sun ri≈øes at 4 a clock in the morning.
Interval between Sun-ri≈øing and the Middle of the Eclip≈øe is 2 ho. 25 min. o ≈øec.
The Duration, according to the be≈øt Ob≈øervations, and Mr. Wing's Tables, is 1 ho. 58 min. o ≈øec. This obtained, I work by this Analogie:

div.p: As the length of the day on which the Eclip≈øe happens, is to 365 days: ≈øo the interval between Sun-ri≈øing and the Middle of the Eclip≈øe, is to the time ere its Effects begin to ≈øhew them≈øelves.

row.cell: Length of the day 16 ho. 20 min. or 1080 m.
Interval between Sun-ri≈øing and the Middle of the Eclip≈øe is 2 ho. 25 min. or 145 min.
Time ere the Effects begin, 49 days.

div.p: Which 49 days numbred from the day of the Eclip≈øe, viz. June 22. the Effects thereof initiate, or fir≈øt begin to ≈øhew them≈øelves, on the tenth day of August following.

Now for the Continuation of the Effects, that is known from the Duration, which is two hours fer√®; Ergo, they will continue in force neer two years from the time they fir≈øt commence, viz. from August, anno 1666. until July, anno 1668.

Thus much may ≈øerve for the Mathematical part: now I come to the A≈øtrological. And therein I ≈øhal fir≈øt pre≈øent you with the Figure of heaven erected to the Middle-time of this famous Eclip≈øe, in the following form and ≈øhape; and afterward with the genuine ≈øignification thereof.

figure.head: Thema Coelicum Eclip≈øis Solaris, 1666 D.H.M. Men≈ø. Junii, 21.18.25. P.M. Sub Lat. 51 deg. 32 mi. ‚òΩ √† [] ‚ôÇ ad ‚òç ‚ôÑ.

list.head: The Fortitudes and Debilities of the Planets in this Eclip≈øe.

div.p: Hence it appears, that Mercury and Jupiter are Lords of this Eclip≈øe, as having the greate≈øt number of Te≈øtimonies in ≈øtrength: the Sun (the Luminary eclip≈øed) is weak by 6 Arguments, and hath not one Fortitude either E≈ø≈øential or Accidental to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him.

div.head: Judicium A≈øtrologicum.
div.p: IN this Ecliptical Figure, the Regal and fiery ≈øigne Leo a≈øcends the Horo≈øcope, and the Sun (the Dominator of that ≈øigne, and Luminary eclip≈øed) is po≈øited in Cancer, a Cardinal-Tropical-Feminine ≈øigne, moveable and watry. As if many matters or things of mo≈øt eminent note, that for divers ages pa≈øt have been flouri≈øhing, fixed, or ≈øtative, are by this Solar Deliquium, portended ≈øubject to a ≈øtrange kinde of in≈øtability, incon≈øtancie, and fluctuation: and this mo≈øt apparent in I≈ølands, and among ≈øuch Nations or People as are ≈øurrounded with, or chiefly live and inhabit by, and upon the Sea. The ≈øigne wherein the Defect happens, is the Horo≈øcope of Holland, and the ne≈øt of the ∆≤nited Provinces, the Seigniory of Venice, Scotland, &c. and they may a≈ø≈øure them≈øelves they are concerned therein: of which more ≈øhall be ≈øaid anon.

It is the Moon, the le≈ø≈øer light, (or rather, a body that is opake, and hath no innate light at all) that thus Eclip≈øeth the Sun, the Royal Lamp of heaven; the glorious Fountain of Light, from whence ≈øhe her ≈øelf receives illumination. I hope and pray, That no actions of Ingratitude, corre≈øpondent to ≈øo unu≈øual an Eclip≈øe, may appear, or be perpetrated in any part of this our European world. The Moon Eclip≈øeth the Sun, in her own dignities; in a place, where ≈øhe hath power to triumph and tyrannize to purpo≈øe. The Sun (≈øay A≈øtrologers) ≈øignifies, the mo≈øt illu≈øtrious and glorious, of Per≈øons and Things: the Moon, the ba≈øest, and most-to-be-contemned and de≈øpi≈øed. I could acquaint you with many ≈øuch kinde of Eclip≈øes, both of former and later times; and with the tri≈øtitious attendants of them: but I would not be thought Dolores renovare, to
renew old Sorrows, or awake the ≈øleeping Errours of either our own, or any other Kingdom or Nation.

A Signo deliquii ≈øumitur judicium generis rerum afficiciendorum. A≈øtrologers in giving Judgements upon the defects of the Luminaries, ≈øay, That the Effects of them ≈øhall fall principally upon tho≈øe kindes of men or things, which are ≈øignified by the ≈øigne wherein the Eclip≈øe happens.

Eclip≈øis Salis in ‚ôã, ‚ôè aut ‚ôì ob≈øcurae, turbae ignobili≈ø
que plebeculae interitus, diuturnae bellorum, ≈øeditiones, & aquatilium marinorum
que & aliorum in aequore degentium magna pernicies. Procl. The ≈øigne wherein this famous Eclip≈øe is celebrated (as you have already heard) is Cardinal-Moveable-Watery, and Foeminine. The learned Proclus ≈øaith, An Eclip≈øe of the Sun in the Watery Triplicity (chiefly the diguities of the Moon, ≈øhe having ≈øignification of the Popular multitude) denotes a rot or con≈øumption of the vulgar ≈øort of people, many rumours and di≈øcontents, great Seditions, Mutinies, and expectations of Wars; a de≈øtruction of Water-fowl, and death of Fi≈øhes; great Inundations, and overflowings of Sea-banks, drowning of many places; with many great and unheard-of mi≈øchiefs, acted and done by and upon the Waters.

In ≈øecundo Decano, ≈øtuvios & fontes ex≈øiccat, incontinentiam, & petulantium mortalibus intentar. Procl. And as very much damage and prejudice to ≈øome people, parts or places, is probable to happen, by or upon the Waters, &c. ≈øo al≈øo it is very likely to fall out unto others, by rea≈øon of a want or ≈øearcity of Waters. And ≈øo ≈øaith the ≈øame Author, in the≈øe words;‚Äî When the Sun ≈øhall ≈øuffer an Eclip≈øe in the ≈øecond Decanate of Cancer, Fountains and Rivers ≈øhall be dried up, and there will be a great want of waters; mach incontinencie among men and women doth al≈øo ≈øucceed; and a great deal of fraud, circumvention and deceit will be practi≈øed.

But now, as this eminent Eclip≈øe falls in a ≈øigne of the Watery Triplicity; ≈øo it happens in a Cardinal Tropical ≈øigne likewi≈øe. And all A≈øtrologers con≈øent, that Eclip≈øes in Aequinoctial and Tropical (which are the onely Cardinal) ≈øignes, are of the must eminent concernment unto this terrene Globe, and pour down their influences upon it the mo≈øt forcibly and violently.

Aequinoctia ≈øigna & Tropica turbulentiora & populariora dicimus, & generaliter ≈øignificant rerum Civilium mutationem, ≈øaith one: (id est) We finde by experience, that your
Tropical and Equinoctial ≈øignes are more violent, turbulent, and popular, then are any of the other parts of the Zodiack; and Eclip≈øes, great Conjunctions, Comets, &c. happening in any of them, are the most remarkable in their effects.

The rea≈øon hereof is neer at hand: the greate≈øt and mo≈øt noble of actions and things (be they Eccle≈øia≈øtical or Civil) are dependant upon Cardinal or Tropical ≈øignes; they are the Hinges or Axis upon which the mo≈øt weighty and illu≈øtrious Per≈øons or Matters (either of Univer≈øal or Particular, Publique or Private concernment) move or turn. And when an Eclip≈øe, Comet, or other Cele≈øtial Phaenomena happens therein, ≈øuch things, or per≈øons, mo≈øt naturally and principally are de≈øigned to ≈øhare in their Influences.

We have in≈øtances familiar enough, in the common vici≈ø≈øitudes of the Weather, of the great verity hereof. For when any grand Satellitium, Conjunction, Oppo≈øition, or Quadrate A≈øpect of the Planets happens to be in Cardinal Signes, the Air is more then ordinarily perturbed; as we ≈øaw it in the Effects of the Quadrate of Sol and Saturn, on March 30. this year, and upon the Oppo≈øition of the Sun and Saturn on June 29. following; as al≈øo, upon the Quadrate of Sol and Saturn on September 27. after that: the≈øe A≈øpects all happening in Cardinal Signes; as may be ≈øeen by the Ephemerides. We know al≈øo, that per≈øons born under Cardinal Signes, are more vigorous, active, and (I was about to ≈øay) violent, then others: as to in≈øtance in the late King of Sweden, Carolus Gu≈øtavus; Oliver Cromwel; the pre≈øent Emperour of Turkey; cum multis aliis, of former and later times. We could prove likewi≈øe, that tho≈øe Kingdoms, &c. who≈øe A≈øcendents are Cardinal Signes, are more ≈øpirituous, couragious, active, furious, mutable, and incon≈øtant, then are other Kingdoms, who≈øe Horo≈øcopes are in other parts of the Zodiack; as Germany, Polonia, France, Saxony, Al≈øatia, Holland, Denmark, and England too; for that is under Aries, and hath been ≈øubject (the more is the pitie) to mutability and incon≈øtancie as much as any other Nation whatever.

But to pa≈øs by this little Digre≈ø≈øion: not onely the Eclip≈øe
is in a Cardinal Signe, but at the time of the defect, the two infortunate Stars (≈øo called by rea≈øon of their intemperate natures and qualities, and the malignant Effects they are always by experience known to ≈øend among mortals) Saturn and Mars, do obviate the Luminaries from Cardinal Signes; thereby making the darkne≈øs much blacker in its effects, then otherwi≈øe it would be. And the≈øe two Planets do not onely con≈øpire again≈øt the Sun, (the Luminary ≈øuffering) and the Moon, the Agent in this Deliquium; but cro≈øs and ≈øquare each other, and that (in ≈øome re≈øpects) maliciou≈øly. As if they intimated ≈øome more then ordinary mi≈øchiefs, and alterations to be (under the influence of this Eclip≈øe) hatching and contriving (either in Italy, Holland, or ≈øome other parts beyond the Seas;) which when brought to pa≈øs, the Projectors them≈øelves (Saturn and Mars) by contending with each other, will but make room for the advancement and promotion of ≈øome yet-unexpected and unthought-of per≈øon or intere≈øt. Mercury ≈øits and ≈ømiles at the forward ≈øolly, and ra≈øh adventures of the other Planets:Planeta qui e≈øt in undecima domo, altior est illo qui in 9, 6, aut 3 est. Haly. Mercurius dominus deli, uii generaliter quidem in illius ≈øtellae naturam ≈øe in≈øinuat, at
que convertitur, cum qua fuerit configuratus, &c. Ptol. l. 2. C. 8. Apotel. 'tis he that is the ≈øtronge≈øt Planet in the Figure, and of all mo≈øt nobly placed in the Heavens. A Planet in the eleventh hou≈øe (≈øaith Haly) is higher then one in the ninth, ≈øixth, or third: And able (therefore) to attempt and compa≈øs nobler things then he.

The nimble Planet Mercury being Lord of an Eclip≈øe, generally a≈ø≈øumes the nature of that Planet with whom he is configurated. Howbeit, as he is the Author of quick and violent motion, ≈øo he intimates celerity in humane actions, affairs, and concernments; irritates much cunning, craft, and ≈øubtilty, lying and deceit, perjury, &c. much robbing both at Sea and Land; makes much controver≈øie in the Cu≈øtoms and Laws of Nations, alterations of old Priviledges, Charters, or Corporations; many Law-≈øuits and unappea≈øable differences he promotes. In the Air (he being cold and dry, and mo≈øtly neer the Sun) he generates high and blu≈øtering winds, great tempe≈øts, thunders and hightnings, ≈øometimes earth quakes, &c. Here≈øies and Schi≈øms get ground under his Regencie, (Europe has no
need of that) and a race of people u≈øually appear, that will contemn Ceremonies, and throw dirt in the face of all Religious Wor≈øhip: he al≈øo denotes depopulations, and a de≈øtruction of things u≈øeful for the ≈øupport of humane life; and hinders the growth of vegetables: he ≈øtirs up di≈øea≈øes of ≈øiccity, as Con≈øumption, Pti≈øick, Fevers, &c. The≈øe are the natural ≈øignifications of Mercury, as Lord of an Eclip≈øe: but as he is in A≈øpect of Jupiter, (though it be by a Quadrate) it is to be hoped that his effects will meet with ≈øome abatement; but much I cannot promi≈øe my ≈øelf, becau≈øe Jupiter is ju≈øt leaving Pi≈øces, and neerly in Oppo≈øition of Mars in this Ecliptical Figure: yet ≈øomewhat he will perform, by vertue of his own benefique nature, and of his having rule in this great Deliquium, next unto Mercury, who≈øe effects I have at large related.

And not onely Mercury hath ≈øignification of the afore≈øaid di≈øtempers, but the Eclip≈øe in general is the fore-runner of many tedious and durable infirmities that ≈øhall afflict the per≈øons of men and women: SaturnÃÑ is in Capricorn in the ≈øixth hou≈øe, (of the Greeks called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , from the great infelicity and unhappine≈øs which di≈øea≈øes bring to mankinde; they being the envious oppo≈øites unto health, which is the greate≈øt ble≈ø≈øing in the world, and mo≈øt of all to be coveted!) and there powerful to do mi≈øchief: Mars al≈øo is Lord of that Angle by Exaltation, and (being in reception and Quartile of Saturn) ≈øhall in part de≈øigne the di≈øea≈øes portended, viz. the Calenture, Jaundies, Impo≈øthumes, Madne≈øs, Pe≈øtilence, Pox, Botches, Inflammations, &c. Wherefore, by rea≈øon of his violence and de≈øtructive poy≈øonous qualities, he is much to be feared. Cave iram Martis: we ought, when in a Figure of an Eclip≈øe we finde Mars in a po≈øition apt for the promoting of mi≈øchiefs, to beware of his raging and thundering threats.

It is the opinion of Hermes, Aphor. 90. that Saturn performs evil more ≈ølowly, but Mars more ≈øwift: and Mars is therefore (≈øaith he) ob≈øerved to hurt more then Saturn. Mo≈øt ≈øure I am, that although Mars, in regard of his velocity and
heat, hurts more, (that is, more furiou≈øly and ragingly) then Saturn doth; yet is Saturn (as I before urged) the author and procurer of the mo≈øt durable mi≈øchiefs and mi≈øeries unto mankinde: And as he (≈øecundum Hermetem) performs evil more ≈ølowly, yet by rea≈øon of his tardous motion, and envious tenacious nature, he is mo≈øt certain to accompli≈øh it the more ≈øurely: and this I am afraid we poor mortals ≈øhall finde and experience to purpo≈øe, from his envious, malignant, and pernicious effects, portended unto us by his po≈øition in this Solar defect.

Surely God is angry with the≈øe We≈øtern parts of the world, and that exceedingly! in that he ≈øhews ≈øo many eminent and ≈øignal tokens of his divine di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt us. But lately, viz. anno 1663. on Octob. 10. was celebrated an unu≈øual Conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter, in the Regal and fiery ≈øigne Sagittary: ≈øuch a Conjunction that happens but once in 795 years, it beginning the circuit of tho≈øe two Planets in the Fiery Trigon See more of this Conjunction in my Dies Novi≈ø≈øimus, or Dooms-day not ≈øo neer as dreaded.

And a little after that, there appeared three dreadful Comets or Blazing Stars, as ≈øo many Monitors of approaching terrours and dangers to befal mo≈øt part of the habitable Globe: tho≈øe Comets having relation in their motion, unto almo≈øt three parts of the whole Zodiacal Circle. And now this year, (as if tho≈øe rare and unu≈øual Phaenomena were not of them≈øelves ≈øufficient to pre≈øage horrour enough to compleat poor Europes already-begun mi≈øeries!) we are fallen under the effects of a Solar Eclip≈øe, in a Cardinal Tropical ≈øigne: and this defect was vi≈øible to all this Occidental part of the world: the glorious Lamp of heaven refu≈øing to afford us his wonted benigne influences, by ≈øuffering (in this defect) his nobler rays to be with-held from us.

As the ≈øad and to-be-lamented effects of the≈øe ≈øeveral Celestial Amba≈ø≈øadours, we have had our ≈øufficient ≈øhare of Wars, the company of that horrid, black and di≈ømal enemy the Pestilence; a mi≈øerable de≈øolation and de≈øtruction by Fire; and all the≈øe too long and too heavie upon us! and yet Gods anger is not turned away, his hand is ≈øtretched
out ≈øtill „Äà‚óä„Äâ
the envious Planet Saturn, and furious Planet Mars (by their male≈øique po≈øitions and configuration in this Solar Deliquium) are yet working more mi≈øchie≈øs and di≈øturbances, in the mindes, manners, and actions of mankinde; and will (by their evil influence) hinder and ob≈øtruct the cour≈øe of things, both in Natural Generation, and in Trade, and in affairs of mo≈øt kindes. God grant a Famine ≈øucceed not tho≈øe ≈øeveral former ≈øeverer Judgements of the Almighty, if it be his ble≈ø≈øed will. Although tho≈øe other Judgements have been afflictions grievous to be born, and eminently terrifying (almo≈øt) unto all ≈øorts of people; yet the lea≈øt part of the Famine will be far more tran≈øcendently intolerable and crued unto mankind, then all the other put together.

Famine (≈øaith one) is ≈øometimes ≈øo fierce, that it makes the mother u≈øe the teeth in ≈øtead of her lips to her own childe; to bite without pitie the infant which ≈øhe u≈øed to ki≈øs; and in ≈øtead of giving it ≈øuck, to let out the bloud of it. God keep ≈øo black an enemy from the doors of all true-hearted Engli≈øh-men I we have had our portion of Plenty, and this in ≈øo great and abundant mea≈øure, that we have wallowed therein: Oh! that we might be able to divert our part of Penury, by acts of Charity, Prayer, and Repentance.

Had we no a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from the Cele≈øtial movers for our Judgements in the≈øe matters, yet tho≈øe ob≈øervations we are able to make from common Experience, might readily inculcate to us a more-then-ordinary probability thereof; ≈øince it is the Order which God and Nature ob≈øerveth, to pur≈øue a Plenty with a Dearth, and to puni≈øh extreme Wantonne≈øs with griping Want.
div.q: Bright mornings oft have blackest afternoons.
div.p:
Ecliy≈øiuÃÑ Solis effectus potentes ≈øunt, unde ≈øi in florentem Me≈ø≈øim inciderint ≈øterilitatem afferunt Seg. 2. Aph. 16 The learned Hieronymus Cardanus tells us, (and I am afraid too oraculou≈øly) that the effects of an Eclip≈øe of the Sun are very powerful, which happening in the beginning of a hopeful and flouri≈øhing harvest, denotes ≈øterility and barrenne≈øs to follow. I fear, I fear, that the great ≈øtrength of Saturn (I
Cadentia ≈øunt ≈øpiritus, & quicquid accidit in eis, dem accidit in ≈øpiritibus. Haly. mean not particularly in this Solar Eclip≈øe, but) in this whole year, and ≈øome years yet ≈øucceeding, will, and doth pre≈øage, not onely Sterility, or a Dearth of Corn, &c. but a de≈øtruction of all things growing upon the earth, u≈øeful for mankinde. He is in a Cadent hou≈øe in the heavens, thence afflicting the Lights: Haly ≈øays, that Cadent hou≈øes are as it were ≈øpirits; and what≈øoever happens in them, (he means either of fortitude or afflication) happens unto the ≈øpirits of men or things. Hence I am fearful, that not onely the ≈øpirits of ≈øeeds of Vegetables will lo≈øe their ≈øoul and vigour, and not be capable of rooting and bringing forth the fruits of the earth, as at othe times. Saturn is a Planet cold and dry; and therefore (in a Phy≈øical ≈øen≈øe) a great enemy to, and hinderer of all Natures products, and indeed of all natural Exi≈øtencies: And he is now po≈øited in Capricorn, in a cold, dry, melancholy and feminine ≈øigne; as if the mo≈øt hopeful conceptions were threatned to be de≈øtroyed in „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or in the womb, and ≈øcarcely ≈øuffered to ≈øee the light; much le≈øs to come to maturity. The learned Rigel, in his 83 Aphori≈øm, ≈øets it down as an ab≈øolute Conclu≈øion, That Saturn is the most pernicious and de≈øtructive in his effects, when he is po≈øited (as now in this Eclip≈øe) in a feminine ≈øigne.
Thus you ≈øee, Authors are po≈øitive and agreeing: An Eclip≈øe in the beginning of a Harvest, denotes barrenne≈øs, ≈øaith Cardan.
The ≈øpirits of Vegetables, &c. are afflicted, ≈øaith Haly.
Saturn is most de≈øtructive when in feminine ≈øignes, ≈øaith Rigel.

The Eclip≈øe it ≈øelf began in June, a little after the beginning of the Summer, viz. when the Grain begins to harden in the Ear. We have had a very dry Summer; a hot and moi≈øt Autumn; (as if the natures of the Sea≈øons were really changed.) Let us petition, that God of his infinite goodne≈øs, would not permit or ≈øuffer our Harve≈øts for ≈øome years ≈øucceeding, either by unkinde and bitter fro≈øts, Mildews, or un≈øea≈øonable Showers, to be either bla≈øted or
lodged, or ≈øuffer other damage or prejudice, before it comes to be fully hardened, and fit for the painful Husbandmans Sickle.

Yet a little further. Sol omnibus Planetis tribuit vires: (they areSegm. 5. Aphor. 171. Cardans words.) The Sun (as he is Rex Planetarum, the King of all Stars) gives ≈øtrength and power to the Planets. And when his ≈øight is hindered, his influence is ob≈øtructed, and Nature receives a check in all her teemings, and is thereby much mole≈øted in her noble≈øt and freee≈øt operations.

Sol omnium fortunarum maxima e≈øt, neque Planeta ullus magis benifious. Card. And, There is no Planet more benefique and friendly unto this earthly Globe, then is the Sun: for he is the greatest of the fortunate Stars, and di≈øper≈øes his happie rays and influences mo≈øt liberally. Great therefore mu≈øt the damages and injuries be unto mankinde, when his mo≈øt illu≈øtrious and nouri≈øhing beams ≈øhall be with-held from them, though but for the ≈ømalle≈øt portion of time: much more, when we ≈øhall be deprived of his friendly rays ≈øome hours together, as now in this Solar Deliquium.

And although there be ≈øome men who weakly maintain, that Eclip≈øes have no more influences upon terrene bodies, then the black-fac'd night; yet deny they cannot, that the one is natural and ordinary, the other prodigious and extraordinary: and certainly their effects mu≈øt be as different as their natures. Nay, they that quarrel mo≈øt again≈øt the influences of ≈øuch ob≈øcurities and defects, cannot (by their quarrelling) anticipate the effects thereby portended, in either their own, or friends Nativities.

The Diurnal motion of the Earth, (or Sun, if people will have it ≈øo) is ≈øuch, that there is an apparent Phy≈øical rea≈øon to be rendred of the common and never-failing intercour≈øe of Day and Night. But Eclip≈øes happening in no ≈øuch order, and at no ≈øuch certainty, (in re≈øpectu temporis) clearly demon≈øtrate the darkne≈øs of the night le≈øs valid and efficacious, then that in Eclip≈øes: the one coming to pa≈øs by a con≈øtant and unalterable Law or Edict of Nature; and the other happening by Natures Decrees al≈øo, but at no ≈øuch certain, di≈øtinct, and determinate times.

Were Eclip≈øes as certain to happen as is ≈øhe night, (I mean, when the ≈øame rea≈øon in Nature is afforded) then ≈øhould we have Eclip≈øes of both Luminaries every month: for, if we con≈øider that the Sun is eclip≈øed onely in his Synod or Conjunction with the Moon; and the Moon ≈øuffers an ob≈øcuration when ≈øhe is diametrically oppo≈øed to the Sun; we mu≈øt conclude the cau≈øe of the Suns Eclip≈øe to be the interpo≈øition of the Moon between him and the Earth; and the cau≈øe of the Moons Eclip≈øe to be the interpo≈øition of the Earth between the Sun and her.

Now we know, that there is not a month pa≈ø≈øeth us, but affordeth a New and Full Moon; yet we may be ≈øix months and more, ≈øometimes, without an Eclip≈øe of either Luminary: Ergo, Eclip≈øes are of far greater concernment unto mankinde, then the Enemies of A≈øtrologie are aware of, who≈øe ignorance in Starry matters, would ≈øeem to make them of one and the ≈øame influence and effect with the nece≈ø≈øary darkne≈øs and ob≈øcurity of the night.

The natural privation of light in the night, is (in its kinde) of as good u≈øe unto all things ≈øublunary, as the ≈øplendour and beauty of the day; and is as nece≈ø≈øarily oppo≈øed thereunto, as the ≈øiceity and calidity of the Summer and Autumn, to the humidity and frigidity of the Spring and Winter. But as it mu≈øt be de≈øtructive to have two Summers in a year, where one is of ≈øufficient force to ripen all that one Spring can produce; ≈øo mu≈øt it needs be contrary to the increa≈øe and nouri≈øhment of the ≈øeminal vertues of all terrene productions, to have a double night; or in the ≈øtead of one, a night and a half, whenas one ≈øingly is endowed with vigour enough, to concoct and allay the heat of bright Phoebus's ≈øcorching rays, that one day affords. I will conclude this Digre≈ø≈øion with an Excur≈øion of the learned Peucer concerning the effects of Eclip≈øes: Quantos incendit ae≈øtus quamdiu flagrantes, Solis ≈øub ‚ôà anno quadrage≈øinno? Quos motus in Orbe Terrarum commovit, cum haec Solis, tum altero anno po≈øt Lunae Eclip≈øis? Nata ex illis & propagata ≈øunt ≈øemina malorum omnium, quae tunc cum no≈øtras urgeant cervices, & vitae fortuni≈øque minitentur,
imme intentent atque in ferant perniciem, evidentius ≈øentimus & ferimus ac deploramus acerbius. Quantas lites, quam ≈øuperba di≈ø≈øidia, & occulta odia, in≈øidia≈øque quam violenta con≈øilia ≈øeverint ≈øtruxerintque quae bella indicerint, quae pericula nocument aque frumento fructibu≈øque crearint, deliquia anni quadrage≈øimi quarti, cum Luna tota, atra caligine, ter foedum in modum deformaretur? Sol plus de unce ≈øui orbis ob≈øu≈øcaretur, adeo, ut in quibu≈ødam locis interdiu ≈øtellae illuxerint, ac con≈øpectae ≈øint; eo ip≈øo, & ≈øequentibus annu, ex eventu didicimus. Ca≈øp. Peue. fol. 661. de A≈øtrolog.

Prudenter Salem con≈øidera; nam judicia Solis non ≈øant oblivioni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ adenda. L. Rigiis. To proceed; we are advi≈øed by Rigel, prudently and warily to con≈øider the Sun, and in no wi≈øe to forget in our Judgements what effects are dependant upon him; chiefly in an Eclip≈øe.

And Leovitius writing upon the great Eclip≈øe of the Sun which was con≈øpicuous upon April 9. 1567. with relation to the great Effects thereby portended, exclaims, Profecto tam tetram ac horrendam Eclip≈øin Solis ab anno Domini 1544. non habuimus, nec etiam multis futuris ≈øaeculis habituri ≈øumus. (i. e.) We verily (≈øaith he) have not had ≈øo horrid and prodigious an Eclip≈øe of the Sun, ≈øince the year of our Lord 1544. neither ≈øhall we in many ages to come, have the like again.

As Leovirius ≈øaid then of that, ≈øo may I ≈øay of this Eclip≈øe; (and I hope, in ≈øome re≈øpects in may be received as a word of welcome to the world; it intimating, though not at pre≈øent, yet a future happine≈øs unto it) we ≈øhall not in many Ages have the like Eclip≈øe again: but (mi≈øtake me not) this I ≈øay not, by rea≈øon of the number of digits eclip≈øed; but by rea≈øon of that part of the Zodiack in which the defect happens, with a regard had unto the many ≈øad attendants it hath, and the ≈øeveral rough concomitants it meets with, in ≈øignification and portent.

Some (perhaps) may wonder I in≈øi≈øt not upon the effects of Jupiter ≈øomewhat more in this Di≈øcour≈øe, he being the next in dignity to Mercury in this Solar Eclip≈øe. But to ≈øuch I an≈øwer, that his benifique Jupiter mu≈øt ≈øuffer many hard≈øhips, run thorow great difficulties, combat with many hazards, torments and afflictions, ≈øuffer ≈øeveral ≈øcoffs & jeers & many ≈øcars, wounds & di≈øgraces, before he can come to ≈øhine, and ≈øhew him≈øelf in his native lu≈øtre, ≈øignification and portent. ≈øignifications are hindered by Mars, (as before I urged) and al≈øo Saturn; ≈øo that
his noble ≈øignifications are herein totally impeded and ob≈øcured, at lea≈øt for a time: but po≈ø≈øible it is, by that time Jupiter comes into Cancer again, the Saturnine evils will be a little blown over, and Europe may then begin to partake of his illu≈øtrious and noble rays and influences; which will then be ≈øo glorious and dazling, that Envie ≈øhall not ≈øtand before them.
Thus far in general: Come we next to ≈øome particulars by this Eclip≈øe denoted.

The Effects (≈øuch ≈øad ones as they are) you have heard of already: my fir≈øt particular Enquiry ≈øhall be of the ∆≤ bi, the place where tho≈øe ≈øeveral before-mentioned Effects ≈øhall operate, or chiefly ≈øhew them≈øelves: And tho≈øe are ≈øuch, as A≈øtrologers (from a large Experience of the beauteous ≈ømiles, and black events of heaven) have placed under the Cele≈øtial Signe Cancer, and its Quadrangle, viz. Libra, Capricorn, & Aries; ≈øome whereof (as you may ≈øee in my Doctrine of Nativities, from pag. 83. to pag. 87. in Part 1.) are Holland, Zealand, Scotland, Granada, Burgundia, Numidia, Carthage, Africa, Bithynia, Colchis, Denmark, Sweden, Germany, England, France, Palestina, Polonia mirtor, Au≈øtria, Livonia, Sabaudia, Thu≈øeia, Ca≈øpia, Maccedonia, Illyria, Thrace, Albania, Bulgaria, Lituania, Saxonia, Ha≈ø≈øia, Thuringia, India, I≈øles of Orchades, &c. for Kingdoms and Countries. And for Cities and Towns, the≈øe: viz. Naples, Florence, Capua, Ferraria, Augu≈øta, Verona, Brun≈øwick, Padua, Am≈øterdam, Venice, Genoa, Con≈øtantinople, Tunis, Cadiz, York, St. Andrews, Lisbon, Antwerp, Arles, Spires, Vienna, Frankfort, Placentia, Oxford, (poor Oxford!) Con≈øtance, Mecklin, Brandenburg, Vilna, Cleves, cum multis aliis, &c. All which Kingdoms, Countries, Cities and Towns, or any of them, I ≈øay, are ≈øtrongly menaced by this eminent Solar Eclip≈øe; and their inhabitants will have great need to make u≈øe of both prayers and tears, to avert the heavie Judgements of a highly-offended God, at this time, and for ≈øome en≈øuing years, impending over them.
A Word unto each of the≈øe Kingdoms and Countries, more plainly.

Holland and Zealand, you are in the fir≈øt and chiefe≈øt place, concerned in this Cele≈øtial Apparition. Saturn is in Oppo≈øition to your A≈øcendent: the Sun is Eclip≈øed in your Horo≈øcope: and the fiery Planet Mars is in Quadrate A≈øpect unto it. Your Trade is in danger of being totally ruined; your Merchants, of being utterly undone: your Great-ones, are at their wits end; and Poor-ones, ready to mutiny for want of Bread! Make peace with England betimes, or ≈øhortly it will be too late for you: a little more ≈øtrugling will reduce you from High and Mighty, unto Poor and Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed States! Let not your own A≈øtrologers (as of late they have done) flatter you with the hopes of what is never likely to happen: for I unfeignedly prote≈øt, all the≈øe (and greater) mi≈øchiefs will fall upon you, unle≈øs you are wi≈øe in time, and by a prudent and ≈øudden Submi≈ø≈øion and ≈øeeking of Peace prevent it.

This was written before the late Rebellion there; but the Caution may ≈øerve for the future. Scotland hath always had the reputation of a wi≈øe Nation: let not an Ignote Zeal again≈øt things indifferent, overcome thy Prudence: Cro≈øs the Proverb which ≈øays, Omne malum √† Boreale. Be peaceable, and be happie.

Granada, thou wa≈øt fir≈øt rai≈øed out of the ruines of Illiberis, and ha≈øt long continued in great ≈øplendour: be not too confident of thy ≈øtrength and riches, but keep peace and amity with thy Neighbour-Princes: pay thy Tribute quietly to thy undoubted Soveraign, and then thou may≈øt e≈øcape returning into thy fir≈øt matter.
Burgundia, thou did≈øt fir≈øt own the God of the Chri≈øtians for thy advantage: it will be for thy profit now, to maintain thy Religion, and thy Peace.
Numidia, be quiet within thy ≈øelf; quell Mutinies and In≈øurrections in the bud; and pray that thy Prince be as fortunate as Ma≈ø≈øini≈ø≈øa was.

Carthage, (once the Lady and Mi≈øtre≈øs of Africa, and ≈øo continued neer 730 years;) thou ha≈øt been often ob≈øcured; now thou art threatned again, but not with total ruine: It was thy Cu≈øtom to crucifie, not onely the unhappie Captain, but even him who≈øe bad coun≈øel had a pro≈øperous
event: Improve at this time the advice of thy vertuous Coun≈øellors, and be happie.
Africa, (the Romane Africa I mean) thy abundant Plenty is turning into Want.
Bithynia, thou wa≈øt not formerly more peaceable, plea≈øant, and fertile, under the Government of the Chri≈øtians; then now thou art likely to prove unquiet, di≈øturbant, and barren, under the Turks.
Colchis, the glory of Armenia, thy Chymical Sun is neer an eclip≈øe; thy Golden Fleece, and all thy Mynes, are departing from thee.
Denmark, thy Prince hath a Royal Gene≈øis, yet he is but a man: let not a Cancerian people by their policy bring thee under water.
Sweden, if Sword and Sickne≈øs get not the upper hand of thee, thou may≈øt do pretty well: thy damage comes from the South.

Germany, be patient a little, and let the Whirlwinde pa≈øs thee; and thy Sun ≈øhall ≈øhine again, and thy Eagle ≈øhall extend her wings, and flie a pitch, beyond the power of Turk or Tartar to mole≈øt thee.
England, be quiet a while, thy Storm is neerly over: practi≈øe Loyalty, keep Peace within thy ≈øelf, and the con≈øpiring world ≈øhall never injure thee.
France, the effects of Med. Coel. to a Square of Mars attend thee: tru≈øt not too confidently to thy Pur≈øe and Power.
Palestina, the Sun's a≈øhamed to ≈øee thy Holy Land.
Polonia minor, thou art falling retrograde under the effects of this Eclip≈øe; there needs no other bridle to keep thee from advancing.
Au≈øtria, cheri≈øh not Factions within thy ≈øelf: thy Eclip≈øe will prove but Platique, and that (≈øine mora) without continuance: thou wilt recover thy glory again.
Livonia, thy Merchants ≈ømart to purpo≈øe; dome≈øtique Quarrels, and petit Tyrannies, bring the ≈øcourge upon thee.

Sabaudia, thou art mole≈øted both at home, and from
abroad, and wilt be for a ≈øea≈øon: afterwards, thou may≈øt of Malvoy, become Salvoy again.

Thu≈øcia, the honour of Italy, for promoting Cele≈øtial Learning; the glory of the world, for unexhau≈øted and never-failing Steel-mynes: pray that thy ≈ølighting the former, bring not upon thee the malevolent effects of the later.
Ca≈øpia, Inte≈øtine Jars, and Forraign Enemies, create much trouble unto thee: be a≈ø≈øiduou≈øly vigilant and preparing, that the Parthian ≈øword prove not too ≈øharp and heavie for thee.
Macedonia, be careful to prevent Fires, and trade not too much We≈øtward.
Illyris, 'tis thy lot to have many Conquerours.
Thrace, thy ancient Cu≈øtom was to mourn at the birth of Children, and to rejoyce at their death: it was a Practice Orthodox and Pious; a≈ø≈øume it again, it may now be nece≈ø≈øary.
Albania, kick not again≈øt thy Superiours, nor thy Peace; le≈øt another Scanderbeg ri≈øe out of thy own bowels again, to puni≈øh thee.
Bulgaria, be wi≈øe; le≈øt thy too ≈øtrict adhering to a Turki≈øh faith, ruine thy ≈øtately Palaces, and de≈øtroy thy Princely Cities.
Lituania, Wor≈øhip and ≈øerve the true God; your Di≈øhpan, or God of Smoke, cannot ≈øave you from common Flames or Troubles.
Saxonia, keep peace with the Emperour, and ward a We≈øtward ≈øtorm.
Ha≈ø≈øia, thy Lion barry is like to lo≈øe his Crown; engage not too far, for fear on't.
Thuringia, Hi≈øtory makes mention of thy having been many times burnt, but thou ha≈øt revived, like a Phoenix out of the a≈øhes, into greater glory. God grant thou may≈øt be ≈øo happie now, and ever.
India, as thy Country is great and populous, ≈øo thy afflictions de≈øigned by this Eclip≈øe, will be great and eminent.

Orchades, thy Swans ≈øing not ≈øo ≈øweetly as in times pa≈øt; and thy great plenty of Fi≈øh, ≈øeems wa≈øted: thy inhabitants grow ≈øluggi≈øh and inactive; Di≈øea≈øes wa≈øte their courage: but you will meet with timely relief and amendment.

Secondly, and not onely to Kingdoms, Countries and Cities, &c. are the≈øe Ecliptical effects carryed or directed; but unto many individual per≈øons, men, women, and children: more e≈øpecially unto ≈øuch, that ≈øhall have either the tenth degree of Cancer, or its oppo≈øite Signe Capricorn their Medium Coeli, Horo≈øcope, or place of either of the Luminaries in their Nativities.

Unto ≈øome per≈øons, they denote death; to others, tedious and durable infirmities; unto a third ≈øort, they denuntiate a Cata≈øtrophe of Honour, and a ruine of reputation, fame, &c. affliction by continual Controver≈øies, vexatious Law-≈øuits, &c. to a fourth ≈øort, de≈øtruction of Parents, friends and acquaintauce, or an ab≈øolute hatred between them and the Natives contracted or procured, no ways reconcileable. To a fifth ≈øort, Impri≈øonments, Bani≈øhments, Exile, the wrath of Princes and Potentates. To a ≈øixth ≈øort, Blindne≈øs, or lo≈øs of one of the Luminaries of their bodies: and this mo≈øt certain, if the Sun and Moon were weak, or any way afflicted at the birth of ≈øuch per≈øons.

Thirdly, ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall be born at the time of this Eclip≈øe, will either ≈øuddenly, (or el≈øe in ≈øome ≈øhort time after it) die: or if for ≈øome competent ≈øpace of time they ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈øs a place among the living, they will live mo≈øt mi≈øerable and di≈øea≈øed; ≈øubject to a thou≈øand troubles and infortunacies, &c. And I could wi≈øh that any ingenious adver≈øary to A≈øtrologie, (for ≈øome ≈øuch I have charity to think there are) would take the pains, and ob≈øerve the births of ≈øuch children, (for I, God permitting life and liberty, intend to do the like) and after a candid in≈øpection, of the Figures, and ≈øerious ob≈øervation of the Natives unto whom they belong, publi≈øh them, either to
the di≈øparagement of A≈øtrologie, or conviction of their former thoughts thereof. The tryal would be ea≈øie, and might either correct the confidence of A≈øtrologers, or better in form the judgements of their Antagoni≈øts.

Fourthly, to put a little more weight in the Seale; per≈øons that ≈øhall be born at the time of this Eclip≈øe, if they ≈øhall prove vital, will be ugly, or of an ill-favour'd a≈øpect; that for their evil looks they ≈øhall be hated and abhorred by many while they do live. The rea≈øon hereof is this: Saturn and Mars, the two infortunate Stars, afflict the Luminaries at the time of this Eclip≈øe: and A≈øtrologers ≈øay, (nemine contradicente) When the Sun or Moon ≈øhall be (an any Geniture whatever) in Conjunction, Quartile, or Oppo≈øition of Saturn and Mars, (chiefly when both of them ≈øhall ≈øo ≈øuffer) it portends an ill a≈øpect, and great detriment and damage to the Natives ≈øight, if not an ab≈øolute blindne≈øs.

But then (perhaps) you'll ≈øay, this A≈øtrological rea≈øon is not Univer≈øal enough: take then a Phy≈øical one: The ≈øight re≈øides in the Eyes, and particularly in the Chry≈øtalline humour there; which is by nature cold and moi≈øt, and governed by the Luminaries of heaven: [for Man, you mu≈øt know, is a „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or little world, and hath a Sun and Moon in him, like the greater:] now this noble and Cele≈øtial humour, being oppo≈øed and oppre≈ø≈øed by one more earthly, (as Saturn properly ≈øignifies) or by one more hot and fiery, (as Mars governs) is attracted beyond its proper and peculiar ≈øeat; and thereby made not onely le≈øs ≈øerviceable, but le≈øs plea≈øant, according to the quantity of the oppre≈ø≈øion it labours under. Whence come tho≈øe unplea≈øant looks, and abhorred defects in many per≈øons, commonly called Purblinde, Squint-ey'd, &c. and ≈øometimes an ab≈øolute blindne≈øs, or total deprivation of ≈øight.

Many more matters might have been ob≈øerved from this eminent and famous Solar defect; but the≈øe ≈øhort Animadver≈øions touching upon the principal things thereby ≈øignified, ≈øhall ≈øerve to illu≈øtrate the effects thereof; and al≈øo to commute for my promi≈øe made in my la≈øt years Ephemeris concerning the ≈øame.

div.head: POST-SCRIPT, Ad Lectorem.
div.p: BEing in London all the late terrible Vi≈øitation, and ob≈øerving this quondam-glorious Citie labouring under the mightie≈øt Di≈øcontents imaginable; ≈øadly lamenting the di≈ømal ≈øight of Coffins, and their Cadaverous gue≈øts; having no other Mu≈øick heard within her, but Bells to a mournful tune, and her inhabitants in every corner wretchedly bewailing the lo≈øs of their Relations of all kindes: And taking notice, that, not onely Empericks, but the learned Phy≈øicians them≈øelves, were deceived in their Prognosticks and Cures of that Raging Pest. 'Tis true, they u≈øed divers Means, to put a check unto its fury; but, as the number of their Antidotes increa≈øed, the Weekly Bills augmented: as if God and Nature were angry beyond an ordinary degree of Pacification, and would not ≈øuffer tho≈øe Celestial influences to be baffled, from whence the≈øe cruel Calamities i≈ø≈øued.

Ob≈øerving the≈øe things, I ≈øay, I was re≈øolved to try how far A≈øtrologie might be ≈øerviceable in this matter, and accordingly took Pen in hand; and (for this dejected Citie's comfort and encouragement) wrote a ≈øhort Di≈øcour≈øe, which I intituled, London's Deliverance predicted, &c.

In which Book, according to the true and plain Rules of A≈øtrologie, I acquainted the world, when the Pest ≈øhould arrive at its greatest height; and afterwards, with the time of its abatement; as al≈øo of the ≈øeveral Countries ≈øuffering thereby.

And although I aimed at nothing in that Tractate, but the comfort of the (then) many ≈øuffering ≈øouls in this great Citie; I have had the hard hap to be mi≈ø-interpreted for
many things therein; chiefly, for my plain di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of this urrifying, but mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary Question to be ≈øcann'd, viz. Whether the Plague be catching.

For my pains in this Enquiry, Mr. John Booker, in his Almanack for 1666. is plea≈øed to ≈øpend above a Page upon me; and urges a Definition of the Plague, and ingeniou≈øly explains it: but yet is plea≈øed to let my Arguments ≈øtand untouch'd, and onely ≈øays, he could in≈øtance the Plague to be infectious and catching by innumerable means, but that he wants room. I ≈øhould (I confe≈øs) have been glad to have ≈øeen his Arguments brought in oppo≈øition to mine; being as ready (if Rea≈øon require) to retract an Errour, as write a Truth. But for any man to ≈øay, he is not of my Opinion, and not to ≈øhew me a rea≈øon wherefore, is not (I conceive) the way to win me unto his.

There is another Gentleman al≈øo, a Doctor of Phy≈øick, (which Title (fairly obtained) and Profe≈ø≈øion al≈øo, I exceedingly honour) hath been pulling at me in Print, for my maintaining the Negative in the Que≈øtion above propounded. This Antagoni≈øt is angry in earne≈øt, and tells the world, That I de≈øerve to be an≈øwer'd by the Magi≈øtrate, and that there is no way to ≈øuppre≈øs my Opinion, or an≈øwer my Arguments, but by putting in execution an Order publi≈øhed in Queen Elizabeth's days.

To which I an≈øwer: If there be any ≈øuch Order as he pretends, I humbly ≈øubmit my ≈øelf and Opinion unto it; as al≈øo unto all other Edicts proceeding from Authority. Contra Legem none≈øt di≈øputandum: and he mu≈øt be ≈øtrangely Rebellious, that oppo≈øeth the Laws he liveth under.

To contemn what we cannot conquer, ≈øome commend as good Policie; and to pretend to an≈øwer a ≈øerious Argument with the power of the Magi≈øtrate, or an Act of Parliament, is (I confe≈øs) the onely infallible way to ≈øtop any Opponents mouth. How like a Philo≈øopher that way of arguing is, let the knowing world judge.

But I believe this Gent. is as bold with Authority, as rigid with me: for I never yet heard or read of any Order publi≈øhed,
to prove the Plague contagious, or to prohibit a di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of that Question; except from his Pen: although I can ≈øay, I have often con≈øulted Poulton.

And con≈øidering ≈øome other pa≈ø≈øages of his, I perceive that he is not more angry at that my Opinion, then at the Cele≈øtial movers, the Stars; whom (≈øaith he) many have accu≈øed as the Authors of the Plague. I have (I acknowledge) in the Book before mentioned, proved the Stars to be (≈øub Deo) the Cau≈øes of the Pe≈øtilence: but nowhere do I bring an accu≈øation again≈øt them, as I know of; believing them free from guilt, and not meriting an Impeachment for the ≈øame; they onely performing that Office therein, which God appointed them for at the beginning.

But this Gentleman (notwith≈øtanding his aim, and fruitle≈øs pains, to render me ridiculous, and the Stars (I ≈øtudie) inefficacious;) is not (in the mean time) aware, of his own running into an Errour of far greater magnitude; viz. in his a≈ø≈øerting the Original of the Plague to have been the ROTTEN M∆≤TTON eaten in the year before.

Now, let any rational man con≈øider whether of the two, come neere≈øt the Truth: I, in a≈ø≈øerting the Stars; or he, in maintaining Rotten Mutton, to be the Cau≈øe of the Pest. An Epicurean may, and frequently doth a≈øcribe more to his belly, then unto tho≈øe glorious and ever-bu≈øied Lamps of heaven. I cannot ≈øtand here to repeat the Arguments I have urged, to prove the Plague contagious; I mu≈øt refer the Reader, for that, to the Book it ≈øelf.

But if Rotren Mutton be attended with ≈øuch fatal effects, why not a Plague every year after a Rot of Sheep? which is the common con≈øequence of every moist Summer. Or, if the Plague were truly the effect of Rotten Mutton; how then holds it true, what he a≈ø≈øerts el≈øewhere, in the ≈øame Di≈øcour≈øe? viz. That the Plague came to us from the Netherlands, and to them from Smyrna, in a parcel of infected goods. Was there a Rot of Muiton in Smyrna too? Ri≈øum teneatis, &c.

To conclude: let it ≈øuffice at pre≈øent, that I deny any ≈øuch way of infection by Goods; and reject the Romance of
his Rotten Mutton: and (as before) do a≈ø≈øert, the Stars (≈øub Deo) to be the true and e≈ø≈øential cau≈øes of all Plagues: and ≈øub≈øcribe unto it.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THe BODY of ASTROLOGY (≈øo often by me promi≈øed) con≈øi≈øting of many various and different Subjects, each of which requires much more Study and Pains then I at the fir≈øt expected, will, I hope, this year be fully ready for the Pre≈øs; I having gone thorow the greatest part thereof already, and doubt not (by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) to compleat it in due time: which when≈øoever done, I ≈øhall (with all Candour and Faithfulne≈øs) make publique, for the Advantage of the Indu≈øtrious Students in this Art, and perfection of A≈øtrologie in the Engli≈øh Tongue.
